section.title: Overview
section.para: The module enables you, on behalf of your company (the importer), to prepare Purchase Orders and subsequently group them to initiate Import Letters of Credit.
In this chapter, we use the terms importer and buyer interchangeably, and we use the terms exporter and seller interchangeably,

section.title: POs and LCs
section.para: The module provides facilities for creating and updating POs and communicating with the exporter and/or bank about them. Thus it is analogous to many other modules in , which provide similar facilities for other products such as Letters of Credit.
In addition, the module provides functions for creating a Letter of Credit from a group of POs. Doing this is called registering the POs.

section.title: Bank Involvement
section.para: The bank associated with these transactions is known as the Issuing Bank, just as in other modules, even though in this case it does not really issue anything. In this module the bank is more of an observer, since no bank approval is needed for POs and invoices to pass between buyer and seller.

If both the buyer and the seller are users of , the POs and invoices pass directly between them, and are sent to the Issuing Bank for information only, enabling the bank to offer services such as financing.

If only one of the companies is a user of , then communications between them are sent via the Issuing Bank. While one company uses to communicate with the bank, the other must use some other channel such as SWIFT TSU.

section.title: Counterparty Access
section.para: If your counterparty (the seller) is not an existing user of , your company can give them limited access to to enable them to receive your POs and send you invoices. They do this using the and modules, which are described in the chapters Purchase Order Advice Module and Invoice Module.
This module is sometimes called the Purchase Order Apply module to distinguish it from the module.

section.title: Submit Function
section.para: In most modules in , the Submit function sends the product (for example, Letter of Credit request) you have created to its intended recipient (in most cases, the Issuing Bank). In the module, the Submit function merely saves the PO ready to be registered to a Letter of Credit.
Registering the PO to an Letter of Credit is the end of the life cycle of the PO. You can subsequently Submit the LC.

section.title: Functions
section.para: In this module you can do the following:

listitem.para: Enter the desired terms of a new Purchase Order and validate these details, or upload a file containing details of several Purchase Orders.
Group the prepared Purchase Orders in order to initiate one or more Letters of Credit.

Display a list of all Purchase Orders that are still pending, which means POs that have been initiated but not yet internally approved. You can open them from this page to update their current content or state.
Browse through all your company's existing Purchase Orders to review their details or history, and optionally print a hard copy of their transaction data.
Delete Purchase Orders, to clean up your workspace of outdated, incomplete or unused/unregistered transactions.
Define the sections to be included in the PO Initiation form, and the formats available for the files you will upload in the Upload function.

section.title: Initiate
section.para: This section describes the PO Initiation function and the forms it uses.

section.title: PO Initiation Options
section.para: This action has several sub-menu items, providing different ways to create a Purchase Order, or to create a template to be used in creating Purchase Orders.

section.title: From Scratch
section.para: Create a Purchase Order or PO template from a blank form.
When you select this option, you are presented with the blank form.

section.title: From Template
section.para: Create a Purchase Order or PO template from a template that you have previously created.
Most of the information for the transaction is defaulted except data such as the expiry date, currency and amount of the new PO.

When you select this option, you are presented with a list of your company's existing PO templates. You can search the list by entering search criteria in the Reference and/or Description fields at the top of the page.

The columns show the Reference and Description of each template. You can modify the description of a template by clicking the Edit
icon, or delete a template by clicking the Delete
icon.
Click in the Reference column to open a new Purchase Order form, populated with the details from the selected template. After completing the form you can save it as either a new PO or a new template.

section.title: Copy From Order
section.para: Create a Purchase Order or PO template from an existing PO. Used in a similar way to From Template.

When you select this option, you are presented with a list of your company's existing POs. You can search the list by entering search criteria in the System Id, Seller Name and/or Currency fields at the top of the page.
The columns show the System Id, PO Reference, Seller Name, Currency, Amount, Issue Date and Expiry Date of each PO.
Click in the System Id column to open a new PO form, populated with the details from the selected existing PO. After completing the form you can save it as either a new PO or a new template.

section.title: Upload Orders
section.para: Create one or more Purchase Orders by uploading a file.

You can use this feature to provide the details in an attached file instead of creating each PO by filling in the long online form used in the From Scratch option. Typically this file will have been extracted from your internal system, and will contain details of one or more POs.
When you select this option, you are presented with a brief PO form, where you enter just the most important data for the transaction, together with the name of the file to upload and attach
The data in the file consists of Line Items, detailing the individual lines of goods to be ordered.
You select the file format from a list of formats defined beforehand using the Parameters > Upload function. You can also select a PO template containing details to add to the details from the file.

section.title: Edit Transactions
section.para: Complete a Purchase Order that you or another user have already started and saved.

When you select this option, you are presented with a list of POs that have been prepared and saved by users in your company (the buyer), but have not yet been completed or have not been successfully submitted because the input user had insufficient authorisation.
You can search the list by entering search criteria in the System Id, Seller Name, Currency and/or User Name fields at the top of the page.
The columns show the System Id, Purchase Order reference, Seller Name, Currency, Amount, User Name (of the user who created the draft) and Input date of each PO.
Click in the System Idcolumn to open the draft for further editing.

section.title: Retrieve Unsigned
section.para: Complete a Purchase Order that you or another user have already started but been unable to submit.

When you select this option, you are presented with a list of POs that have been prepared and saved by users in your company (the buyer), but have not been successfully submitted because the user had insufficient authorisation. (Records that were simply saved with no attempt to submit them are not included.)
You can search the list by entering search criteria. The criteria you can enter are the same as for the Edit Transactions option, and the list contains the same columns.
Click in the System Id column to open the PO in a non-editable mode, so you can review the data and perform the submission.

If you have sufficient authorisation in your profile, you can submit multiple records in a single operation directly from the list. Each record in the list has a check box which you tick to select it. A button at the end of the page submits all the selected records.

The result of the action is then returned, with a list of items that have been successfully sent to the Issuing Bank, next to the list of the records pending from an additional validation. The updated list of unsigned records is then also displayed.

section.title: Letter Of Credit
section.para: Create one or more Letters of Credit from the existing unregistered Purchase Orders.
This enables your company to accumulate POs, and decide from time to time to create LCs from several POs.

When you select this option, you are presented with a list of your company's existing unregistered POs. You can search the list by entering search criteria in the System Id, Seller Name and Currency fields.

The columns show the System Id, Seller Name, Currency, Amount, and Input of each PO. The Purchase Orders are shown grouped by Entity (if any), Currency and Seller Name, since POs not sharing these criteria cannot be grouped into the same LC.
Each record in the list has a check box which you tick to select it. Click Submit at the end of the page to submit all the selected records to initiate a Letter of Credit.
The list of unregistered PO records is then redisplayed, updated.

As you select POs, a popup shows the total value of those selected. This will become the value of the new LC. In this popup, you can click a magnifying glass icon to display a list of LC Templates (created in the Import Letter of Credit module). Select one from the list. In fact, the details from the PO are used mainly to build the LC Description of Goods, and it is often convenient to use a template to provide other details.
All POs in an LC must be for the same currency and same seller. Therefore, if there are POs with different currencies and sellers, several LCs are created.
When a PO is registered in an LC, it is marked as LC Registered. The PO's life cycle is finished.

section.title: Pending Orders
section.para: Display a list of your company's Purchase Order records that are pending.
This is typically used by a manager to monitor the consolidated list of PO transactions that have been prepared but not yet submitted.

It also gives quick access to the actions required to interact with a given transaction record. Therefore, depending on the state of the record, you can open the record either in edit mode or in review/signature mode (only if submission has been attempted but it is still pending for additional credentials).
The list displays Purchase Order records of types:
and whose transaction statuses are:

listitem.para: Incomplete (the input user saved it as a draft, using Save; it could be retrieved using the Edit Transactions menu item)
Uncontrolled (the input user tried to submit it, using Submit, but did not have sufficient privilege; it could be retrieved using the Retrieve Unsigned menu item)

section.para: Each record is shown with its System Id, Entity/Buyer Name, Type, Status, Seller Name, Currency, Amount, Input Date and Users.
There is also a field where you can select an Output Format for the results:

listitem.para: Screen (default) returns the list of matching records on the same page with the usual sorting features.
CSV downloads the report to your machine as Comma-Separated Values file.
Spreadsheet downloads the report to your machine as a Microsoft Excel compatible file.

section.para: You would typically use the CSV or SpreadSheet option if you want to export the list as a report to use it or customize it further in your office productivity tools. When the browser displays the File Download prompt, you can choose to save the file (whose default name is pendingPO.xxx) or directly open it which will launch Excel if it is available on your workstation.
Each record is shown with one or two action icons, depending on its status:

section.title: Order Inquiry
section.para: Display a list of Purchase Orders that your company (the buyer) has initiated, so that you can check their status or anything related to their details or history.
Note that once a PO is registered into a Letter Of Credit, its workflow is completed and its status won't change.
The list is not displayed until you have entered search criteria and clicked Search. To display all records, enter an asterisk in any of the criteria fields.
Each record is displayed with its System Id, Entity/Buyer Name, Folder ID (of the LC it is registered to), PO Reference, Seller Name, Currency, Amount, Issue Date, Status and Child Reference.
As in the section Pending Orders, there is also a field where you can select an Output Format for the results.
The Status column shows the current state of the transaction and can have the following values:
Each record is shown with two action icons:

entry.para: Visual
Description
Open a popup window displaying the current master details of the record.

(History) Display a list of all events for the record, detailing the complete history of the file. For each event in the life of the file, the list shows the Release Date, the Type of the event, the Status, the Currency and transaction Amount (e.g. the Purchase Order amount), and the identities of the input and supervising users.

section.para: On the History page, you can click in the Release Date column to open a popup window showing full details of each event. Within the popup, the Event Details section shows the key details of the event. It shows any additional instructions and attachment provided by the customer as well as the bank's comment and attachments given as part of the reporting.
If the Event Details header in the popup window shows a Release Date/Time, it means the time the validated transaction event was released by the buyer to the seller.
The Date/Time field that accompanies a Message header means the time the reporting message was released by the seller to the buyer.

You can also export the history report as an external file in CSV format, by choosing CSV in the Output Format list box and clicking the icon
. The name of the file downloaded is the System Id of the transaction together with a .csv extension - for example, if the PO has the system identifier PO0110001008., the filename is PO0110001008.csv (where the first "O" is the letter O, not zero).

section.title: Order Maintenance
section.para: Perform maintenance tasks on Purchase Order records handled by your company. You can assign an entity to a record, and you can delete from the system outdated transaction records or records whose status has been marked as Purged.

note.para: Deleted records are physically removed from the system. This task should therefore be conducted with great care!

section.para: This action has several sub-menu items.

section.title: Set Entity
section.para: Assign an entity to a Purchase Order record that currently has none.
When you select this option, you are presented with a list of records that have no entity assigned. Click in the System Id column to open a form where you can assign an entity to the record.
Note that this action is not validated against the Jurisdiction matrix. All transactions of the current files are updated.

section.title: Unsigned Orders
section.para: Display a list of Purchase Order records that have been prepared by users in your company but that have not yet been submitted.
Some of these records may be out of date and will never be submitted. A client user with administrator's privilege should delete these pending records.

You can delete multiple records in a single operation directly from the list. Each record in the list has a check box which you tick to select it. A button at the end of the page deletes all the selected records.

section.title: Not-registered Orders
section.para: Display a list of Purchase Order records that have been prepared by users in your company but that have not yet been registered to a Letter of Credit..
Some of these records may be out of date and will never be registered to a LC. A client user with administrator's privilege should delete these pending records.

You can delete multiple records in a single operation directly from the list. Each record in the list has a check box which you tick to select it. A button at the end of the page deletes all the selected records.

section.title: Purged Orders
section.para: Display a list of Purchase Orders that have been marked as Purged, by the Issuing Bank's Trade Services team (messages to purge POs are sent by the bank to your system by other means such as SWIFT TSU). You cannot initiate further amendments or messages on such a transaction, and can only use its data for inquiry purposes, or as a basis for a new PO using the Copy from Order function.

You can delete multiple records in a single operation directly from the list. Each record in the list has a check box which you tick to select it. A button at the end of the page deletes all the selected records.

section.title: Registered Orders
section.para: Display a list of Purchase Orders that have been registered to a Letter of Credit. In such a case, the PO workflow is completed and its status won't change. You cannot reuse it to initiate new LCs, and can only use its data for inquiry purposes, or as a basis for a new PO using the Copy from Order function.

You can delete multiple records in a single operation directly from the list. Each record in the list has a check box which you tick to select it. A button at the end of the page deletes all the selected records.
